body: Tina is a little girl who says she sometimes feels ''like a fish out of water.'' In short order, she actually becomes one -- well, not a fish exactly, but a certain finned mammal. Tina (Audrey Lucas) is the heroine of ''A Dolphin Up a Tree,'' a children's musical by Kimberly Foster, presented by the Magic Bridge Theater Company. In need of a school
title: FAMILY FARE; When Magic Goes Awry

body: There is something magically glorious about snow at Christmastime in New York. This is especially true for someone who grew up in Washington, where it snows little, and whose work has taken him and his family around a snowless world, from Miami to West Africa to Hawaii and, now, to Tokyo. When our first child, Will, was pushing 3 years old, he ran
title: From Afar, Christmas Remembered; Will Has His Way In the Snow

body: ANYONE who looks for an apartment in New York carries around a mental list of what would be nice, as well as the knowledge that something will have to be sacrificed. title: Habitats/St. Johns Place, Prospect Heights, Brooklyn; Finding an Apartment That Has Everything

body: FOR 17-year-old Rebecca Richman and her boyfriend, Travis, this spring was their first spring in love, and like many New York lovers, they often wandered deep into Central Park, feeling as if they were alone in the world. Day after day, they held hands, spread out a blanket near a pond, had picnics and took pictures of each other. But on June 21,
title: Her Hoop Dreams

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; A Twofold Mission Of Piety and Pop

body: To the Editor: I read with dismay the destruction of Ellen Halloran's beloved tree (''Mourning a Humble Ailanthus,'' Soapbox, Oct. 8). I too lived in the Village with a similar green canopy of trees that have mercifully survived in an odd little green lot on Downing Street, thanks to a trust, rumor has it. I can attest to the immeasurable serenity
title: Who Keeps Track Of the Tree-Cutters?

body: BEGUN in 1829 as a Sunday School festival, Anniversary Day (or Brooklyn Day) was transformed into a celebration of the founding of Brooklyn, and in 1959 the Board of Education extended the holiday to Queens. The holiday is usually celebrated the second Thursday in June. The celebrants pictured above are from a 1910 photograph by J. J. Levison, from
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT PARK/PROSPECT HEIGHTS; Viewing Brooklyn's Backyard

body: For more than a decade, 11 shuttered and abandoned buildings have stood among the neat single-family homes on Dean Street in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. title: Residential Real Estate; Home Building Project in Brooklyn, Halted Since 1984, Is Being Revived

body: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: CENTRAL PARK ROBBERY Two women were robbed at knifepoint early yesterday morning as they sat on a bench in Central Park, the authorities said. title: Metro Briefing

body: SHE was sitting in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden the other day, feeding a duck out of her hand. She looked serene, as befitted a soon-to-be-ordained Zen priest. ''You can perform legal marriages,'' she said of her impending priesthood, which ''gets the legal clergy status, those parking spaces that say Clergy Only.'' She laughed. Angel Kyodo
title: COPING; A Zen Priest and the Art of Black Serenity

title: FAMILY FARE; Unburied Treasure

title: Bitter Primary Contest Hits Ethnic Nerve Among Blacks

body: For 14 months after Amy Watkins died with a knife in her back on a tree-shaded sidewalk in Brooklyn, David Jamison managed to escape the notice of dozens of detectives hunting for her killer. He cut off his dreadlocks. He apparently spoke little about the crime. He spent nine months in Pennsylvania until returning to Prospect Heights, the
title: Woman's Arrest Led to Brother as Suspect in '99 Murder

body: In a murder case that drew national attention but seemed to be growing colder by the month, the police have charged two men with the fatal stabbing of Amy Watkins, a 26-year-old graduate student, on a Brooklyn street a year and a half ago. The man who police say did the stabbing, David Jamison, 27, admitted his role in the killing in a videotaped
title: Two Charged in '99 Stabbing Death of Student in Brooklyn

body: Lawrence Watkins went through more than a year of tears, condolences, sleepless nights, speeches and letter-writing before his memory began the merciful act of burying his daughter's murder. Then yesterday afternoon, a single telephone call unraveled all that. Mr. Watkins stood in silence in his living room as a police officer relayed the news: one
title: News of Arrest Renews Survivors' Pain

body: The official term is ''supplemental adjustment,'' but opponents call it ''the poor tax.'' title: Rent Board to Vote on Extending Much-Debated Surcharge

body: None of the facts have changed in the year since Amadou Diallo died in his doorway: four white police officers, 41 bullets and one unarmed black man. But in neighborhoods from one end of the city to the other, away from the daily protests over the slain man and the political posturing, New Yorkers' attitudes about the police have begun a subtle
title: SHADES OF BLUE: A special report.; Diallo Case Yields More Nuanced View of Police

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Capturing Time: The New York Times Capsule'' includes some of the nearly 50 design proposals received in a New York Times Magazine competition. The winning capsule design, by the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava, has its own special display.

body: PROSPECT HEIGHTS Views of Japan From a Time When Change Was at Hand Everyday life in Japan at a crucial time, just after Commodore Matthew Perry opened the nation to the West in 1853, was immortalized in the woodblock prints that Utagawa Hiroshige made of the city Edo. The Brooklyn Museum owns a complete set of the prints, made between 1856 and
title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: GO out in Brooklyn? On the weekend? For groovy New Yorkers, that was once an unbearably tepid proposition. Russian immigrants may drink vodka in Brighton Beach leisure palaces, and Trinidadians let loose to soca near Nostrand Avenue. But the students, artists and hipsters seeking the cultural edge started their evenings on the subway to the Village
title: Brooklyn Nights Turn Brighter

body: To the Editor: The only way to combat these problems is to give communities control over their public space. Given a say, New Yorkers would likely choose to have streets redesigned in a way that would make them quieter, safer, greener and again accessible to the vast majority of city residents -- those who do not own cars or are too young to drive.
title: Traffic-Slowing Measures In Bronx Fall Short . . .

body: A Brief Life, Burning Bright In the original stage adaptation of Anne Frank's diary, there is never any mystery surrounding her fate. Even children who do not know her story will recognize the note of loss in the first scene, when Otto Frank returns to the Amsterdam hideaway and retrieves his daughter's journal.
